captions.text: (GASPS)

So, what is empathy and why is it 
 VERY different than sympathy?
Empathy fuels connection.
Sympathy drives disconnection.
It's very interesting.
Theresa Wiseman is a nursing scholar

who studied very diverse professions 
 where empathy is relevant

and came up with 
 four qualities of empathy.

Perspective taking - ability to take 
 the perspective of another person,

or recognise their perspective 
 as their truth.
Staying out of judgment -

not easy when you enjoy it 
 as much as most of us do.
(AUDIENCE CHUCKLES)

Recognising emotion in other people, 
 then communicating that.
Empathy is feeling WITH people.

I always think of empathy 
 as this kind of sacred space.

When someone's in a deep hole 
 and they shout from the bottom...

..And we look and we say, "Hey!" 
 And climb down...

Sympathy is, "Ooh!" 
 (LAUGHTER)

"It's bad, uh-huh?" 
 (LAUGHTER)
"Uh... No. You want a sandwich?"

Empathy is a choice 
 and it's a vulnerable choice.
In order to connect with you,

I have to connect with something 
 in myself that knows that feeling.

Rarely, if ever, does an empathic 
 response begin with, "At least..."
(LAUGHTER)

Yeah. And we do it all the time 
 because, you know what?

Someone shared something with us 
 that's incredibly painful

and we're trying 
 to "silver lining" it.

I don't think that's a verb, 
 but I'm using it as one.

We're trying to put a silver lining 
 around it.
So, "I had a miscarriage."

"At least you know 
 you can get pregnant."

"I think my marriage 
 is falling apart."
"At least you have a marriage."
(LAUGHTER)

"John's getting kicked out 
 of school."
"At least Sarah is an A-student."
One of the things we do sometimes

in the face of very difficult 
 conversations
is we try to make things better.

If I share something with you that's 
 very difficult, I'd rather you say,

"I don't even know what to say. 
 I'm just so glad you told me."

Because the truth is, rarely can 
 a response make something better.

What makes something better 
 is connection.

comments.text:
I remember when I was so flustered over my abusive ex, and people would 
say, "at least he's out of your life now." No, he wasn't. He was using our 
child to taunt me! Needless to say, I didn't get much support from 
"well-meaning" friends and family during that time.﻿
comments.author: Cry For Justice

RSA Short, Dr. Brené Brown reminds us that we can only create a genuine

own fragilities. Click here to watch:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Evwgu369Jw﻿

comments.text:
It's explained very well but I don't know it comes through properly how 
tough and heavy it can be to be empathic. Rather than being able to "be 
there" for someone, all I feel is my energy being drained - and the feeling 
after is like trying to get out of quicksand, so sometimes I rather just 
show sympathy, because it's lighter and easier.﻿

comments.text:
This is wrong. Empathy is understanding the journey to how the person feels 
now. Sympathy is understanding the end feeling.  So Marriage falling apart, 
empathy is being able to think about how that person has felt with that 
happening and what they've been thinking. Sympathy, is oh they must feel 
sad and worried I know them feelings. ﻿

comments.author: John Taylor

comments.text:
We need to bring empathy back, America! I'm serious as a heart attack! We 
need to embrace the reality that despite what the thought-police say, we DO 
NOT have to be the same gender, race, or orientation to relate to each 
other!  Hell, I work in inner-city San Francisco and I'm the only white guy 
at work, and I'm close friends with my co workers who are black. We need to 
actually practice what Martin Luther King Jr preached—judge only by the 
content of one's character!! We are making this complicated. Remember the 
K.I.S.S. rule in school? Keep it simple, stupid....﻿
comments.author: Andrew Mitchell

comments.author: vmoreno777

comments.text:
This was an interesting take on empathy vs. sympathy, but I have to say 
that I disagree completely.  I dislike it very much when someone tells me 
that they know how I feel when I know (and so do they) that it's a lie.  I 
never tell someone that I know how they feel when I have not been through 
what they are going through.  Also, I appreciate the 'at least' statements 
because they are true, and they are a look on the bright side.  Your take 
on these concepts seems to not place any value on honesty.  ﻿
comments.author: Jason Steiner

comments.text:
I can relate to this message very well, having lost my wife to cancer 
recently.  I struggled at first to compare "empathy" to the "sympathy" I 
had received from those who were reaching out to help.  It was the 
"empathy" of caregivers that helped me through, as well as a thorough 
reading of Dr. Kathleen Brehony's book, "After The Darkest Hour -- How 
Suffering Begins the Journey to Wisdom."  Holt Paperbacks. New York City, 
CY.  2001.﻿
comments.author: 861Sailor

comments.text:
"Our true friends are those who are with us when the good things happen. 
They cheer us on and are pleased by our triumphs. False friends only appear 
at difficult times, with their sad, supportive faces, when, in fact, our 
suffering is serving to console them for their miserable lives."﻿

comments.text:
I don't like how she's trying to give the word sympathy a bad vibe. 
Sympathy IS feeling what another person is feeling. It's not some 
half-hearted version of empathy as the speaker seems to suggest. What she's 
describing when she says sympathy seems to be indifference or 'not making 
an effort'.﻿
